title: What will US holiday season retail sales be for 2021 relative to the 2020 holiday season?
possible_answers: Higher by more than 0.0% but less than 2.5%
Higher by more than 5.0% but less than 7.5%
preds:
$777.3B
Holiday retail spending in 2020, which, despite the COVID-19 pandemic, was an 8.2% increase over the previous year.
Source: National Retail Federation
Consumer spending up. Holidays back in order.
Much less than 1% chance of December coming in low enough to change the outcome at this point. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit#gid=0

A continuation of the 2021 sep/oct estimates, even following the nov/dec drop in 2020, would still mean a ~13% year-over increase. Weaker employment numbers , increased inflation, and dwindling savings will likely impact this but all that's been in play for a while now.
Spending will increase due to improved wages and eagerness to be face to face with families. But tempered by inflation, supply chain constraints and fear of new Covid variant for the future.
mostly because free covid lunch money......

Thanks @cdob63 for the article: https://apnews.com/article/business-lifestyle-holidays-shopping-f280f3afa3edf048e468aac33d9eb9a2 "U.S. holiday sales last November and December rose 8.2% in 2020 from the previous year, according to The National Retail Federation, the nation’s largest retail trade group. The trade group predicts 2021 could shatter that record, growing between 8.5% and 10.5%." Supply issues could weigh on numbers but items seem to be snapped up as soon as they're available, and larger items can still be pre-ordered. As much as it's a problem we seem to be doing surprisingly well at just kicking the problem farther down the field.
Inflation alone will account for about 5%.  Interesting, though, the stores  are short on inventory for many items.  Real growth may disappoint on the downside.
It is shaping up to be a good year. However, supply chain problems may take their toll

https://apnews.com/article/business-lifestyle-holidays-shopping-f280f3afa3edf048e468aac33d9eb9a2
About the fourth graf in says the National Retail Posse predicts numbers in the 8-10% range.    I'll go with that for a while.

October number continues to increase, no sign of it returning to trend so far so increasing confidence in the last bucket. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit?usp=sharing

Heavily increasing confidence in the last bucket. It looks like a sudden drop of the magnitude needed to fall out of the last bucket would essentially require a recession. I think it will eventually return closer to trend (I've seen econ people on Twitter talking about how currently spending on goods is way up and services down) but I don't think it will be sudden and not in the next few months. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit?usp=drivesdk
Looks like things are running hot and will continue to do so as pointed out by @Emking and @ryan-beck. Add in the inflation rate and it seems likely to be up substantially

Currently running about 13% above this time last year. While there is recession risk, it's looking likely that between inflation and sales growth, this lands in bin 5. Note that the average growth in sales over the last 28 years has been 4.2%.

Still way above trend, and we'd have to see a pretty sudden and steep decline for it to drop into the territory of the lower buckets. Shifting toward the higher end. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit?usp=sharing
SCALING DOWN ON THE NOTION THAT TRANSPORTATION DIFFICULTIES WILL QUASH SALES/ Transportation interuption are going to devastate retailers.

Going up on the top two buckets. Retail sales would have to decrease substantially to land below 5% over 2020. I expect retail sales to decrease because we're way above trend, I'm just not sure if they'll decrease so substantially so soon. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit?usp=sharing

"The 2021 holiday shopping season could be marred by out-of-stock goods and shipping delays as the recent floods in Europe and China exacerbate already strained global supply chains. Western Europe and China’s Henan province — a key transport hub and home to several major businesses — are grappling with the aftermath of devastating floods."
"Even if there are deals for the peak online shopping season, Joshi said it’s likely there will be fewer and the discounts will probably be smaller. Prices may also go up for some goods, he said."
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/03/shipping-crisis-strikes-black-friday-shopping-amid-europe-china-floods.html One one hand inflation could certainly increase the number and savings over the last year could support it. On the other restricted supply and pandemic fatigue could hamper it. I'm still of the opinion the crowd is high on this forecast but not sure by how much. Back to school spending may be the first chance to see where appetites are at.

The current spending path leads to an estimated 15% year-over-year growth rate for the Nov/Dec months (which had stabilized in 2020). To be less than a 7.5% growth rate, we would need to see a significant recession in the coming months. While that risk does exist, the proper weighting on those odds is likely lower than assumed.

+ inflation well underway in delivering those numbers
- rising number of covid cases (delta variant) endangering growth
Americans feel much better than last year. It's almost shopping season. Unemployment has declined dramatically.

Availability of goods could become a problem.
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/15/china-covid-cases-causing-higher-shipping-costs-delayed-goods.html "Ports in Guangdong, including Yantian, Shekou, Chiwan and Nansha, have barred vessels from entering ports without advance reservations and will only accept bookings for export-bound containers within three to seven days prior to the arrival of vessels.
Major shipping companies have warned clients of vessel delays, changes to port call schedules, and the possibility of skipping some ports altogether.
The world’s leading container line Maersk said increased the duration of expected delays at Yantian to 16 days from 14 days previously.
[...]
[Flavio Romero Macau, a senior lecturer in business at Edith Cowan University in Perth and an expert in supply chains] Romero said: 'There was such a fast recovery post-Covid, with people spending like crazy on TVs, PlayStations, cars etc, the system is out of balance. Covid has created a big puzzle and it takes a long time to put it back together.' " https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jun/16/covid-outbreaks-in-chinese-ports-could-cause-global-goods-shortages Freight rates from Oct 2021 through Dec 2021 approach 24,000USD and counting in expectation of delays at the two critical ports of Guangzhou (Guandong, Shenzen).
https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/energy/freight/freight-route-td22-baltic_quotes_globex.html (TD22; Tanker Route for 270,000 metric tons for US Gulf Coast to China)
https://www.drewry.co.uk/supply-chain-advisors/supply-chain-expertise/world-container-index-assessed-by-drewry

April was up about 11% over the 2020 holiday season. But looking at the trend we're clearly above trend. Some of that is to be expected due to reopening and a surge in demand, but I think there's plenty of possibility for reversion to the mean here. For one, stimulus checks went out in mid March. I think there's a good chance May could drop down from the March and April numbers since those might have been juiced by stimulus checks. I do think there is a lot of potential for high numbers this holiday season, but the effects of reopening might be counteracted a bit by the fact that we've been above trend and the effects of stimulus checks might fade. Here's a google sheet I put together with the current numbers and a plot: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zkHqZdy_2qgwelFtMvlYgWpm8LgI0cPS3Zpg8oN4Zys/edit?usp=sharing

Pulling the trend it clearly shows the crazy amount spending has increased this year. Make sure to compare with the numbers of 2019 or previous as well since COVID lowered a lot of the spending early in 2020.

First thought: People sent more gifts because they couldn't be together in person last year, and because they had more funds (from what they didn't spend on travel costs). But if I'm reading this correctly, the category includes all non-auto travel costs, dining, experiences.... So yes, significantly higher. We're all realizing how precious the opportunity to be together and create memories is.

Range for the last 5 years has been between 2.8 and 6% with last year being on the higher end, implying that the pandemic didn't substantially impact spending. With that in mind it seems most likely that it will fall in a similar range so I'll put most weight in the 2.5-5% bin. I suppose it could go either way past there; increased travel expenses could lower retail spending, or increased prices, savings, and wages could bump it up. This might be a very boring prediction but I'll just do a curve out from the middle and see how the year progresses
